addressleaf.section:
To my L. T
re
r 29 June 1592.

page.lettertext:
fol.225r
[To my L.]
Trea
s
May it please yo
r
good L.
Steenwicke
being yelded, wherof I have advertised
e occurrence before, it is now in consultation w
t
the states
at are heere, whether
it were c
o
venient to goe against
Coevoerden.
It is a very strong castel
in
e lande of
Drente,
and is distant Southest about 10 leagues fr
o
Steenwick:
where the garrison of
e enemie doth exceedingly annoye both
Frise
and
Overyssel.
The
states of Frise
doe urge it hard, alleaging
at Steenwick
will profit them litle, unles they may have Coevoerden. W
ch
is answea-
red againe by some other of
e Provinces,
at their armie hath bin toiled,
and is greatly diminished both in strength and in number: and that
Coevoerden will be found to be as strong a place as Steenwicke.
That it is not possible, they should speede of their purpose, except they
should bring their artillery thither: w
ch
must all be done by land, and w
th
a mervelous charge, and daily danger of loosing all. For o
r
forces not
surmounting the number of 5000 foote, and 1400 horse, and overwearied
already w
th
the services at Steenwicke, if the enemy should soddainly ass
e
-
ble a greater power, f or w
ch
e bruit is already
at he maketh
p
paration,
they should never have
e meanes, to retire their people and munition.
They are come to no c
o
clusion, because
e Martial C
o
manders are absent
from hens. But
e mater is c
o
mitted to
e
Councel of estate
, and to the
Deputies of
e Provinces,
at are abiding at
e Campe. In
e meane season
those
at are heere in
e assembly of
e states, have written their advise,
at they thinke it not expedient, to undertake
e siege of Coevoerden. But
notw
t
standing their writing they are in some doubte, least
e earnestnes
of Frise will induce
e Councel
a
d
Counte Maurice
to satisfie their humo
r
.
I would be willingly there my selfe, to knowe
e course that it held
in all their proceedings, and to report every action assuredly unto yow.
But because I doe attend; w
at
her
M
tie
will determine about the sending
into
Britaine,
and how
e offer of
e states is accepted in that behalf,
(for to
at effect they call upon me) and for as much as their residence
is allwaies at
e Hage, for w
ch
of force I should returne upon receat
of any letter, I have thought it my best to c
o
tinue heere still, untill
at yo
r
next shall come to my handes.
And so I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. June 29 1592.
